fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Software Server*. Using *JIRA Software Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSWCLOUD-14245].
  {panel}

The OnDemand instance I'm using for this example is: https://simpleltc.atlassian.net

A customer noticed that certain repos that were connected are missing project issue keys in the regex, so these keys do not show as "linked" within Bitbucket commit view. Two examples of these repos:

https://bitbucket.org/simpleltc/lib-infrastructure/admin/links -- (this repo only lists the BAC project regex)

https://bitbucket.org/simpleltc/analyzer-rules/admin/links -- (this repo lists BAC,SUP,WUI,AN projects)

It is my understanding that these regex values should contain ALL of the projects. I've disabled the repo under 'DVCS Accounts' and re-enabled, but it still shows only one project for the lib-infrastructure repo. This behavior seems very inconsistent.
fields.summary: JIRA issue key regex is inconsistent across Bitbucket repos

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Software Server*. Using *JIRA Software Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSWCLOUD-14242].
  {panel}

Steps to reproduce:
# create a pull request with source from branch A and destination to branch B (suppose the commits to be merged contain issue key ABC-123)
# synchronize the repository so that the commits to be merged are recorded and the PR is associated with issue ABC-123 on the Development panel
# update the pull request to change destination to branch C, so that the commits with issue key ABC-123 are no longer in the list to be merged
# synchronize the repository
# result
#* expected: the PR is disassociated with the issue ABC-123.
#* actual: the PR is still associated with the issue ABC-123.

*Workaround*: Do a full synchronization on the affected repository from the "DVCS Accounts" page.
fields.summary: Pull requests are associated with incorrect issues after destination is changed

fields.description:
This is related to https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/DCON-43.

When syncing, request my return with "400 Bad Request" or other error messages. Currently this will cause an unhandled JSON exception and the result is that the sync status contains both success and error messages.

We should advice the user that the sync failed partially and that a resync is recommended.

Video Recording: http://screencast.com/t/NzleE60VLG2 

- Add public repo "https://bitbucket.org/farmas/testrepo-qa"
- Notice that the Post-Commit Hook is displayed as "https://syd-gs-testing-055.jira.com/BitbucketPostCommit.jspa?projectKey=QA&branch=testrepo-qa" 
- Click on "Post Commits"
- Notice that the Post-Commit Hook is displayed as "https://syd-gs-testing-055.jira.com/BitbucketPostCommit.jspa?projectKey=QA&branch=default"

*Expected*: They should be the same, however, I am not sure which is the correct one.

- Note that providing the wrong Post-Commit Hook to BitBucket will cause subsequent commits to not be processed.

fields.description:
Forking is encouraged in Bitbucket as an easy way to make feature branches (outside of Git itself), creating duplicates of Repositories.

However, every time a Repo is forked, every smart commit within is processed again in JIRA (likely because it's technically a new repo). If you make smart commits within your fork, then merge them back into the master, every smart commit is processed once more. 

* Steps to reproduce
# Create a new Repository
# Enable Smart commits for your entire team account (and auto add smart commits for new Repos)
# Fork your repo and work in the new fork (all of these should remain under the team account)
# Commit to the Repo with a smart commit, log some time
** This smart commit will now properly be registered in JIRA
# Merge into your master branch
** This will re-process the smart commit made in the fork
# Fork again
** Your commit will now be processed AGAIN.
# There are now 3 comments and 3 times the work logged against a single issue.

Because Forking is encouraged in Bitbucket, this behaviour causes trouble in JIRA as multiple work logs are added and people who use JIRA for reporting can get confused.
fields.summary: Forking in Bitbucket with Smart commits enabled causes double/multiple entries

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
The functionality is described at https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BITBUCKET/Configure+Automatic+Team+Invites.

*Issue*: 'Developers' group is added to a newly created organization as default group and thus all newly created JIRA users are automatically invited to the group if the group exists on Bitbucket.

*Expected solution*: The group should be added for OnDemand instances and only for integrated accounts but not for BTF instances.

*Workaround:*
# Go to DVCS Accounts page 
# Choose Configure automatic access for the corresponding organization
# Uncheck the Developers group if present
# Press Save button

fields.description:
When configuring GIT DVCS connection you are able to enter a URL mismatch in the Git account connection while generating the OAuth tokens.
h3.Reproduce
   - registered JIRA DVCS on github, and entered the wrong callback url, per the documentation [HERE | https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/AOD/Linking+a+Bitbucket+or+GitHub+repository+with+JIRA+OnDemand] (See Screenshot)
  - this allows you to enter the incorrect information without error
   - Then when configuring the DVCS on JIRA, at step 2 point 10 per the documentation, click "add"
   - Because the callback address was wrong, github signalled an error.
   - *Error*: Blank page is returned with an error similar to:
{code}
https://not_a_correct_url.atlassian.net/?error=redirect_uri_mismatch&error_description=The+redirect_uri+MUST+match+the+registered+callback+URL+for+this+application.&error_uri=https%3A%2F%2Fdeveloper.github.com%2Fv3%2Foauth%2F%23redirect-uri-mismatch
{code}
NOTE: https://not_a_correct_url.atlassian.net/? from the example above will be the misconfigured *Authorization callback URL* from your GIT settings

h3.Workaround
Confirm that the *Homepage URL* and the *Authorization callback URL* are the same, and are your Base URL
exe: 
Correct:
 - Homepage URL: https://example.atlassian.net
 - Authorization callback UR: https://example.atlassian.net

Incorrect:
 - https://example.atlassian.net/secure/Dashboard.jspa
fields.summary: Entering mismatched URL for GIT causes error

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
When there is a branch whose name is the sha of one of the contained commits this creates a cycle in the branch traversal algorithm, causing the DVCS connector synchronisation for that branch to loop infinitely.

Here is an example from https://github.com/ahalife/django-mediasync

{code}
* commit fa6a134cf4fe7b57ba2143a88ae489d4af735129 (origin/8b09e8b1f5faa83f71721b5ef97f424813e312ff)
| Author: jcarbaugh <jcarbaugh@gmail.com>
| Date:   Mon Sep 28 01:29:32 2009
| 
|     Updated README examples to use the default long paths instead of the JS/CSS path shortcuts.
|  
* commit 8b09e8b1f5faa83f71721b5ef97f424813e312ff
| Author: Jeremy Carbaugh <jcarbaugh@gmail.com>
| Date:   Sat Sep 26 07:44:33 2009
| 
|     base URL config on MEDIA_URL setting
|  
{code}

The issue here is that the [GitHub commits API|https://developer.github.com/v3/repos/commits/#get-a-single-commit] interprets the {{:sha}} path parameter as a sha *or* a branch name so when the DVCS connector requests sha={{8b09e8b}} GitHub actually returns commit {{fa6a134}} (the head of the branch called {{8b09e8b1f5faa83f71721b5ef97f424813e312ff}}). The sync algorithm then goes on to fetch the parent of {{fa6a134}}, which is {{8b09e8b}}, and the cycle repeats.
fields.summary: Branch name equal to commit sha on GitHub causes infinite loop in synchronisation

fields.description:
After setting up OAuth, connecting directly to our GitHub organization (containing our "golden" repositories), only shows the public repositories. This is with the OAuth set up properly with the Organization being the owner of the Application connection on the GitHub side. From our side, it appears that the problem is directly related to the repositories being owned by an organization, rather than by a specific user. 

Connecting to a specific user in the organization that has full admin rights to the entire organization will show any private forks of those same repositories, but the actual master repositories are not shown (only the forks). I have tried with the OAuth Application setup in GitHub being owned by the Organization and being owned by the user with full admin rights to the organization, neither works - both exhibit the same behavior. 

There is a thread in Atlassian Answers that has gone unanswered, with other people reporting the same behavior: https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/68418/connecting-to-my-github-organization-only-shows-the-public-repos
fields.summary: GitHub private repositories owned by an Organization not showing

fields.description:
Using WebHooks, I have observed a reproducible issue using JIRA and Bitbucket (both Atlassian cloud hosted).

The fix for un-sync'd DVCS repos (found at http://bit.ly/1NNEYgj) suggests using a POST service from Bitbucket, however, the lastest Atlassian Cloud indicates that Webhooks are now preferred, and POST service will be deprecated.

Following the "POST Service" method with Bitbucket works as follows:
* Create an issue in JIRA with default status of "To-Do"
* Also create a branch for this issue in a linked Bitbucket repository (no probelms there)
* Create a Bitbucket POST service with the following:
*     "https://<my site>.atlassian.net/rest/bitbucket/1.0/repository/<repo id>/sync"
* Create a smart commit with #In-Progress to update the issue status
* Navigate to JIRA issue
* Observe that everything is immediately updated: the dev panel, the status ("In-Progress")

However, when I attempt to do the exact same procedure using a webhook instead, I find something ODD occurring:
* Repeat steps exactly as above, but create Bitbucket WebHook instead of POST service
* Navigate to JIRA issue
*     Observe that nothing is updated, and the commit is not seen
* Navigate to JIRA "DVCS Accounts" page
*     Hover over the "Sync Repo" circular icon
*     Observe the timestamp indicating that the repo successfully sync'd at the correct time
*     However, how could this be? The DVCS page says the repo DID sync, as it was told to. Yet the issue page does not reflect the update. 

So my question becomes, how can a DVCS repo sync via a WebHook, but not actually update Project issues to reflect commits and dev activity?

And why would this differ between using WebHooks vs POST Service?
fields.summary: DVCS Accounts page shows timestamp for potentially failed sync

fields.description:
h3. Summary
The first commit of a newly created repository on Bitbucket sets the "_SMARTCOMMIT\_AVAILABLE_" flag to "f", which makes the smart commit fail on JIRA.
h3. Environment
JIRA Cloud
Affected version is 5.0.0-D20160601T054537

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Have JIRA Cloud and Bitbucket integrated
# Create an empty repository on Bitbucket
# Clone it with _git clone_ to your machine
# Add a file/folder to it
# Commit the changes making sure you add a message that references an existing JIRA issue and use "_#comment_" smart commit (Ex: {{git commit -m "ABC-123 #comment This is a comment."}})
# Push the changes with {{git push}}

h3. Expected Results
On JIRA you can see the comment added to the ABC-123 issue
h3. Actual Results
The comment isn't added.
 
h3. Notes
Checking JIRA's database you can see the "_SMARTCOMMIT\_AVAILABLE_" flag is set to "f" instead of "t" as it should because a smart commit was performed (see the _MESSAGE_ column).
{noformat}jira=> select * from "AO_E8B6CC_CHANGESET_MAPPING" where "RAW_NODE" like '%5e3c0fc%';
 AUTHOR  |     AUTHOR_EMAIL      | BRANCH |        DATE         | FILES_DATA | FILE_COUNT | FILE_DETAILS_JSON | ID | ISSUE_KEY |                           MESSAGE                           |            
       NODE                   | PARENTS_DATA | PROJECT_KEY |                    RAW_AUTHOR                    |                 RAW_NODE                 | REPOSITORY_ID | SMARTCOMMIT_AVAILABLE | VERSION
 
---------+-----------------------+--------+---------------------+------------+------------+-------------------+----+-----------+-------------------------------------------------------------+------------
------------------------------+--------------+-------------+--------------------------------------------------+------------------------------------------+---------------+-----------------------+--------
-
 fwillig | fwillig@atlassian.com | master | 2016-06-21 14:11:09 |            |          0 |                   | 57 |           | PAC-5 #comment First commit on new repository with comment. | 5e3c0fc07e3
09f67d0f217e292e1acef4fdf7efc | []           |             | Felipe van Schaik Willig <fwillig@atlassian.com> | 5e3c0fc07e309f67d0f217e292e1acef4fdf7efc |             0 | f                     |       3
                                                                                                                               :                                                                          
                                                                                                                                                                                                   
(1 row){noformat}

h3.Workaround
Add the comment manually to the JIRA issue, or only add comments from the second commit on.
fields.summary: Smart commit from the first commit on an empty repository doesn't work

# Link JIRA to Github via DVCS Connector as per [this|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BITBUCKET/Linking+Bitbucket+and+GitHub+accounts+to+JIRA] guide
# Navigate to {{GitHub >> Account Settings >> Repositories >> Settings >> Webhooks & Services}}
# There will be 2 webhooks created that links back to JIRA

h3. Additional Information
Using DVCS Connector version 1.4.3, only one link will be created.

Currently pull request webhooks and post commit webhooks uses the same REST endpoints with different request types. JSON for pull request and web form for post commmit hooks.

We should use different rest endpoints for them.
fields.summary: JIRA and GitHub link creates 2 Webhooks

!DevelopmentSectionIsMissing.png!
# navigate to _JIRA Administration > Manage Add-Ons > System >_ *Development Integration Plugin* is disabled. JIRA throws ERROR when administrator try to to Enable this plugin

{code}
ERROR admin 1303x349x1 1qqeu45 127.0.0.1 /rest/plugins/1.0/com.atlassian.jira.plugins.jira-development-integration-plugin-key [atlassian.plugin.manager.DefaultPluginManager] There was an error loading the descriptor 'null' of plugin 'com.atlassian.jira.plugins.jira-development-integration-plugin'. project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
Here is a description on how DVCS connector synchronises BB/GH commits with JIRA issue.
* Initially after linking new repository to JIRA we use BB/GH API to retrieve ALL commits in the repository. 
* After this initial synchronisation connector does only INCREMENTAL synchronisation - it retrieves only changesets that were commited after the last synchronisation. 
* To find out which changesets to retrieve, connector remembers the changeset with latest date and keeps the date in LAST_COMMIT_DATE variable. When doing incremental synchronisation we ask BB/GH api to return latest changesets and use only those where commit date of changeset is >= LAST_COMMIT_DATE.

This way if JIRA is down for some time, users can continue commiting. When JIRA goes back up, connector retrieves all the commits from latest up to LAST_COMMIT_DATE.

The problem with this approach is when users don't push their commits immediately:
* Let's say on Tuesday *userA* commits and pushes his commit 
* DVCS Connector will catch and synchronise the commit and set LAST_COMMIT_DAY to Tuesday
* On Wednesday *userB* pushes his commit that was commited on Monday. The commit date for this commit is Monday.
* DVCS Connector will never synchronise the commit because commit date (Monday) < LAST_COMMIT_DATE


REST API differences
Bitbucket and GitHub APIs behave differently and different approaches will have to be used to fix it.

GitHub
GitHub API (https://api.github.com/repos/jirabitbucketconnector/missingcommits/commits) returns changesets ordered by commitDate. Changeset for each branch have to be retrieved separately.

Bitbucket
Bitbucket API (https://api.bitbucket.org/1.0/repositories/jirabitbucketconnector/missingcommits/changesets) returns changeset ordered by push date. All changesets from all branches are returned from same REST call.

fields.description:
This happens after we changed from {{select("ID,*")}} to {{select()}} in DCON-468.

The {{AO.stream}} method would only select the "ID" column and fail to lazily load the other columns when given a query with {{select()}}.

To fix this, either use {{find}} or explicitly specify the columns in {{select("columns")}}.

There are multiple places that use {{AO.stream}} but all of them uses only the "ID" column, except for the {{SmarcommitOperation}} class.

Smart commit processing will fail with the following message:
{noformat}
2014-10-02 17:47:36,415 DVCSConnector.SmartCommitsProcessor:thread-2 WARN admin 1049x1700x1 1yahiq0 0:0:0:0:0:0:0:1 /rest/bitbucket/1.0/repository/21/softsync [plugins.dvcs.smartcommits.SmartcommitOperation] Failed to process smartcommit operation. Cause = class java.lang.NullPointerException : null
{noformat}

This is because the {{getMessage()}} call returns null and {{parseCommitComment}} would throw npe when processing the message.

This affects JIRA 6.3.7, which has DVCS Connector 2.1.23.
fields.summary: Smart commits are not processed

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
The DVCS connector uses the custom regex matching linker with Bitbucket. This works, but is case sensitive (BB-12345 would match when bb-12345 wouldn't).

Bitbucket also has a Jira linker which should just handle the case sensitivity just fine.

So, it would be great if either the regex was modified to be case insensitive or the Jira linker was used.
fields.summary: Linkers on Bitbucket are case sensitive

- http://screencast.com/t/uRGLanQG6bY0 
- Got to bitbucket connector configuration screen
- Add public repo url "https://bitbucket.org/farmas/testrepo" to project QA.
- Click on Force Sync

*Expected*: Error saying that there is no repo in that location
	
*Actual*: IndexOutofBounds exception
fields.summary: ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException when force syncing a bitbucket repo

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
This issue was submitted to support, but they were not helpful, and I had to figure it out myself.
https://support.atlassian.com/browse/JSP-120166

I hadn't realize that a separate tracker was maintained for the DVCS connector, otherwise I would have come here first, where I would be able to get a hold of a dev!


Original ticket:


Environment is Ubuntu 11.04 Natty with Postgres SQL 8.4.8.
Upgraded working system from 4.4 to 5.0.
Upgraded all plugins.
Restarted JIRA.

Installed DVCS connector to connect to our GitHub and BitBucket repos and get source commit messages listed with issues.

Immediate exception when clicking on the 'DVCS repositories tab'. I would speculate a relationship was not properly updated / deleted during the upgrade process. Exception message follows:

fields.summary: DVCS Repositories tab (under Admin -> Plugins -> Source Control) throws a Postgres Exception

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
Create a project/repository mapping.
Found: When synchronizing occurs, the branch of the changeset is ignored, all changesets are linked to matching issues.
Expected: When synchronizing occurs, if the branch of the changeset does not match, it should be ignored.

This also came up when deleting repositories too because the branch information was not stored in the issue mapping.  This meant if you deleted a repository, the issue mappings still existed, and viewing the issue (without a valid project mapping) would cause an exception.
fields.summary: Issue Mapping ignore branch restriction

fields.description:
Issue cloned from https://studio.atlassian.com/browse/GHC-30

- Create a project with key "QA"
- Add an issue (QA-1)
- Associate a github repo wit this project
- Commit a change with commend "Fix for qa-1"

*Expected*: Commit to become linked with issue QA-1
	
*Actual*: No link is created.
fields.summary: If a commit message contains issue key with different casing it is ignored.

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
Whenever a commit is logged in BitBucket or GitHub the DVCS connector doesn't trigger the smart commits such as #resolve #comment ..etc I have tested most of them and it doesn't work since the deployment of version 1.1.

Example commit that I have tested:
- SEC-2 #time 2d 5h #comment Task completed ahead of schedule #resolve
- SEC-2 #resolve #comment test resolve
- SEC-2 #resolve test resolve
fields.summary: Git Smart Commits doesn't work since the OnDemand 174

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
I found a similar ticket filed against STASH (https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/STASH-3529) and used it for this one since they did a much better job outlining the problem.

merge commit messages result in duplicate time entries in JIRA when using Smart Commits.
Steps to reproduce:
Create a branch and commit a change with "KEY-123 #time 10m"
Create a pull request for the branch and merge it
The merge commit that Stash creates will contain "KEY-123 #time 10m" again
20 minutes will be logged against issue KEY-123
Expected behaviour:
Only 10 minutes should be logged against KEY-123
fields.summary: Merge commit messages result in duplicate time entries in JIRA when using Smart Commits.

h3. ***Current Behavior***
Newly created users do not receive BitBucket invites when automatic access is configured.

h3. ***Expected Behavior***
Newly created users receives BitBucket invites when automatic access is configured.

h3. ***Steps to Reproduce***
# Log into JIRA as a user with administrative rights.
# Navigate to the JIRA Admin pages.
# Choose DVCS Accounts from the Add-ons section.
# The Manage DVCS Accounts page displays. 
# Locate the account to configure.
# Press the settings  icon and choose Configure automatic access from the menu. The Configure automatic access dialog appears. It lists the groups for the Bitbucket account.
# Select the groups you want new users assigned to.
# Press Save.
# Create a new user in JIRA

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description: When attempting to add a Github repository, the organization owner generated the oauth key and secret.  The JIRA administrator was able to use the oauth key, secret, and the authorized Github user with owner privileges. The JIRA administrator is provided a authorization token.  The Github owner who is also a jira-developer can use the authorization token to log into their Github account which then forwards to JIRA to complete the authorization cycle.  However, when the Github owner uses their JIRA credentials to complete the authorization, he is presented with an error saying he does not have permission to access the page.  As far as I can tell you must be both an Github owner and a JIRA administrator to link via the DVCS plugin.  We have several working linked accounts however they were all made by having both Github owner and JIRA administrator permissions.  How is the linkage accomplished if you don't have privileges in both places.
fields.summary: Owner of Github repository unable to use auth token in Jira unless administrator

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description: We have a project that has the key P4F and any commits to it with the Github connector does not work. I tried with a dummy project that has key TEST and it works fine. From the documentations the format has to be 2 upper case characters but it should also work for any alpha numeric characters as well.  We don't want to change our keys as we would have to back up all of our data and change xmls around, and then change the db reference to reference the new project.
fields.summary: Smart Commits do not work when Project has numeric characters in key
